seg.output: Henrych Strüby expresses his best wishes and wishes for innocence of life from the Lord to the most faithful pastor and doctor of the church of Zurich, Heinrycho Bullinger. Knowing that you find idle talk unpleasant, I have followed brevity, most learned Heinrych. In short, accept that the state of the Evangelical cause is in a state of turmoil in the Rhine Valley. For we ministers of the Gospel have been forced (which is not unknown to you) to suspend our harps with which Christ should be sung, as we read was done to the Israelites taken to Babylon. I took care to give these letters to our president, which had been given to me by the Senate of Zurich. After he quickly read them, he responded with revulsion, and said in a sublime way that which had been demanded of him by the Five Cantons and the Orators of Glarus and the messengers of the Abbot of Cella, that he would execute it until something else is commanded to him. Therefore, our people are deprived of the fodder of souls, while others boast here and there that they have true and undoubted faith, which is not the case with us. For if our faith were ratified and founded on the Evangelical Scriptures, we would not be silent as fish. But so are the wicked customs of Trasonum and so they are accustomed to speak.

Take then, briefly, that the state of the gospel is in turmoil in the Rhine valley. For we all ministers of the gospel have been compelled (which is not unknown to you) to suspend our harps with which Christ should be sung, as we read has been done to the Israelites taken to Babylon. Therefore, most excellent brother, if you have any good advice (if you can spare time from your business), write to me. All things are full of all those vices of which Isaiah speaks in chapter one, as it is, where God is absent.

seg.output: I know that you would find a long speech unpleasant, so following your advice, most learned Heinryche, I will make it brief. In brief, then, accept that the state of the gospel is turbulent in the Rhine Valley. For all of us ministers of the gospel have been forced (which you are not unaware of) to suspend our harps, with which Christ should be sung, as we read happened with the Israelites taken into Babylon. These letters that I have been given by the Senate of Zurich I have taken care to give to our president. On quickly reading them he responded with revulsion, and almost said in a lofty manner that what had been demanded of him by the Five Cantons and the orators of Glarus and the messengers of the abbot of Kelle, he would execute until something else is commanded him. Therefore our people is deprived of spiritual nourishment, while others elsewhere boast that they have true and unquestionable faith, which is not the case for us. For if our faith were validated and founded on the gospel letters, we would not be as silent as fish. But such are the ways of the iniquous Trasons and such is their manner of speaking. So you, most excellent brother, if you have any good advice (if you can because of your business), write to me. For it will be a great ornament to you that we miserable ones are saved by your kindness. What more is there to say? All is full of all those vices about which Isaiah speaks in chapter 1, as is usual when God is absent. You would think it were conspirators in all wickedness. So much is it full of blasphemy, conspiracies, murder, perverse and corrupt judgements, that I believe the Sodomites will be judged less severely in the last judgement. Therefore our church has nothing left in the face of this world but “Christ and him crucified” [1 Cor 2,2], although with some hope (whether true or false, I am in doubt) that our friends in Zurich have taken up our cause.

seg.output: I know that an empty speech would be unpleasant for you, so I followed brevity, most learned Henry. In short, take it that the state of the evangelical cause is tumultuous in the Rhine Valley. For we all ministers of the Gospel have been compelled (which is not unknown to you) to suspend our harps, with which Christ should be sung, as we read was done with the Israelites carried away into Babylon. These letters I had taken care to give to our President, which he quickly read and answered with loathing and said as though in a sublimity that what was commanded to him by the ambassadors of the Five Cantons and Glarus, and also the messengers of the Abbot of Cella, he would perform until something else is commanded to him. Therefore, our people are deprived of the food of souls, while others boast here and there of having a true and undoubted faith, and we do not. For if our faith was ratified and founded in the evangelical writings, we would not be mute like fishes. But such are the wicked customs of the Trasones, and so they are accustomed to speak. You therefore, most excellent brother, if you have any good advice (if you can spare it, due to the business), write to me. For it will be a great ornament for us miserable ones to be saved by your benefit. What more is there to say? Everything is full of all those vices of which Isaiah speaks in chapter 1, as it is where God is absent. You would think they had all conspired to every wickedness. So everything is full of blasphemies, conspiracies, murders, perverse and corrupt judgments, that I believe the Sodomites will be judged more lightly at the last judgment. Therefore, our church has nothing left before this world except “Christ and him crucified” [1 Cor. 2:2], although with some hope (true or false, I doubt) we are nourished that your people of Zurich have taken up our cause. You, I beg, think this way and be persuaded that all refuge of the good is placed in you and your like-minded in our great calamities with which we are oppressed. Therefore, take courage so much as is needful for the recovery of the entire evangelical affair.

seg.output: Knowing that you find long speeches unpleasant, I have followed your lead, most learned Heinryche, and kept this brief. So take this that the state of the Evangelical cause is tumultuous in the Rhine valley. For we Evangelical ministers are compelled (which you are not unaware of) to put down our harps with which Christ ought to be sung, just as we read happened to the Israelites when taken into Babylon. I took care to deliver these letters to our Governor, which he read through quickly and with disgust, and with a lofty air declared that he would do as he was commanded by the Five Cantons and the Orators of Glarus, and the messengers of the Abbot of Cella, until he received other instructions. Therefore our people are deprived of spiritual nourishment, while others here and there boast of having a true and unquestionable faith, something we cannot do. For if our faith was ratified and founded on the Evangelical scriptures, we wouldn't be mute like fish. But such are the customs of the wicked Traso, and thus they are accustomed to speak. So, most excellent brother, if you have any good advice (if you are able to despite your other affairs), write to me. For it will be a great honor for us poor folk to be saved by your kindness. What more need be said? Everything is filled with all those vices of which Isaiah speaks in chapter 1, as is the case where God is absent. One would think they had conspired for every kind of wickedness. So much does everything seethe with blasphemies, conspiracies, murders, perverse and corrupt judgments, that I believe the Sodomites will be treated less severely in the final judgment. Therefore our church has nothing to show before the world except for "Christ and him crucified" [1 Cor 2:2], though we are nourished by the hope (whether true or false I am unsure) that the people of Zurich have taken up our cause. So, I beg you, think thus and persuade yourself that all refuge of the good lies in you and your like in our great calamities under which we are oppressed. Therefore be so courageous as is necessary to recover the entire Evangelical cause. For you can, for I know you to be a modest, prudent and far-removed-from-all-greed man, and also one of great labor and great industry. So at this time I wish that the light of your genuine piety, virtue, faith and also candor would shine forth.

For we all ministers of the gospel have been forced (which is not unknown to you) to suspend our harps, with which Christ should be sung, as we read was done with the Israelites taken to Babylon. I have taken care to deliver to our president these letters which I have received from the Senate of Zurich. When he quickly read them with disgust, he spoke as if sublimely saying that he will execute what is demanded of him by the Messengers of the Five Cantons and Glarus, as well as those of Abbot of Celle, until something else is ordered to him. Therefore, our people have been deprived of the food of souls, while others boast here and there that they have a true and undoubted faith, which we do not have. For if our faith were true and founded on the evangelical letters, we would not be silent like fishes. But such are the ways of wicked Traso and they usually speak like that. Therefore, most excellent brother, if you have any good advice (if you can find the time among your occupations), write to me. For it will be a great ornament to us wretched ones to be saved by your kindness. What more? Everything is full of all those vices of which Isaiah speaks in chapter 1, as it happens where God is absent. One would think that everyone had conspired to do all wickedness. So much do all things boil with blasphemies, conspiracies, killings, perverse and corrupt judgments that I believe the Sodomites will be judged more lightly. Therefore, our church has nothing left before this world except "Christ and him crucified" [1 Cor 2,2], although with some hope (true or false, I do not know) we are nourished that the people of Zurich have taken up our cause. So, I would like you to think as such and persuade yourself that all refuge of the good is placed in you and those like you in those great calamities in which we are oppressed. Therefore, have the courage that is needed to recover the entire evangelical cause. For you can, for I know that you are a modest and prudent man, far from all greed, and besides of great effort and great industry. For this time I wish that the light of your piety, virtue, faith and courtesy may truly shine forth. If those who have profited from it recognize how much you care about them, they will think that they owe you everything. And there are a lot of things that will need to be remedied. Therefore, if my judgment of you should be wrong, and you can not bear the burden, you will find a Theseus, namely Christ himself. Finally, for your kindness towards me, I have great thanks for you and on account of this I will earnestly and diligently care for all things that I know you want. If you want to respond, the one who brought these papers to you will bring them back to me.
Take care of yourself. Greet my most pious wife with your whole family.
1532, 15th of August.
Heinrychus Strüby, unworthy minister of the gospel in Marpach among the Rhine Valley, the lowest and most subservient of your brothers, and this from a pious heart.
To the most learned and pious Master Heinryche Bullinger, teacher of the holy church of Zurich, most beloved in Christ.
